ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

RELOCATION OF 1- and 2-ROOM HDB TENANTS


    1. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development (a) if he will give the number of residents already relocated from 1-room and 2-room flats affected by the Housing and Development Board's relocation exercise, as at the latest convenient date; (b) what steps are being taken to assist residents who cannot be relocated from these flats; and (c) whether adequate 1-room and 2-room HDB flats will be retained for future need.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, 23,701 tenanted rental units were affected when the relocation exercise commenced. By 1 January 1989, tenants in 23,254 units (or 98% of the total) had been relocated.

    The remaining 447 cases are being offered rental flats in the same or nearby estates. HDB will give them priority if they intend to purchase flats.

    The HDB will retain an adequate number of 1-room and 2-room rental flats for those who require transitional housing or the few who are unable to purchase their own flats.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tiong Bahru GRC): Sir, could some attention be paid to giving a face-lift and improving these flats before the town council takes over?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know what the Member means by "these flats". Does he mean the flats affected by relocation?

     Dr Vasoo: I mean those 1- and 2-room flats not affected by relocation.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, where the flats are to be cleared and demolished, I see no purpose in giving them a face-lift. But those that are going to be retained will be given the usual face-lift in accordance with the cyclical repairs.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh (Non-Constituency Member): Can the Minister tell us whether residents have been forced to get out of their flats?

Column: 370



     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, once a block has been identified for re-location and everybody who is in that block is given notice to move, they can move to another rental flat or they can purchase another flat. If they want to purchase another flat, of course as I mentioned, they will have priority. In addition, they will be able to purchase a flat without having to make any downpayment. They will get 100% loan for the purchase of a flat provided it is not bigger than a 4-room flat. So every assistance is given for them to move. But they have to move because the block cannot be demolished and the place cannot be redeveloped if it is occupied.

MRT NORTH-EAST ROUTE
(Construction of)


    2. Mr Goh Choon Kang asked the Minister for Communications and Information whether any decision has been taken with regard to the Mass Rapid Transit Corporation's plan for a North-East route which will cover Serangoon New Town, Jalan Kayu and Punggol.

     The Minister for Communications and Information (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government has decided, in principle, to extend the MRT system in a north-easterly direction, from the vicinity of Chinatown and the City to the vicinity of Punggol and Jalan Kayu. The timing for the construction will, of course, depend on the development of housing estates in the north-easterly sector, because unless there is sufficient demand for the MRT, the MRT will not be economically viable.

    Presently, MRTC, URA, and HDB are studying possible route alignments for the MRT extension bearing in mind the future housing and urban developments along that corridor. Detailed MRT engineering and soil studies will begin when HDB and URA have completed their plans.

DRUG PROBLEM
(Assessment)


    3. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for Home Affairs if he will give an assessment of the current drug problem and the steps which are being taken to strengthen the control of drug flow through the Woodlands check-points.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, the drug problem in Singapore is under control but I must inform the House that we are very concerned because the overall drug supply in this region continues to deteriorate. The Golden Triangle region (the border area formed by Burma, Laos and Thailand) where opium is produced remains a big threat. This is because bumper harvests have been recorded since 1981 and more opium is expected from that region. Neighbouring countries, such as Malaysia, Thailand, Hong Kong, have also reported increased seizure of narcotic drugs in 1988. Correspondingly, Singapore has also detected increased inflow of heroin last year.

    Last year, the main drug of abuse was heroin, with 85% of addicts being on that drug. 5,451 drug addicts were arrested, of which 23% were identified as new addicts. We are also concerned with the increase in the proportion of Malay heroin addicts, especially the increase of new Malay heroin addicts. In 1983, they comprised some 40%, which increased to 69% in 1988. However, the incidence of school children and SAF military personnel abusing drugs is still very low.

    Most of the drugs enter Singapore through the Woodlands Checkpoint. It is being smuggled by both Malaysian and Singaporean 'ant-traffickers'. The number of Malaysian traffickers detected has also increased over the last two years. In 1986, 46 were detected; in 1987, 68; and last year, 85.

Column: 372



    To curb the inflow of drugs through the Woodlands Checkpoint, several measures have been taken. First, we have set up a Woodlands Task Force comprising officers from CNB, Customs, Police and Immigration to complement Customs' efforts in detecting the illegal smuggling of drugs. This Task Force uses narcotic detector dogs to help sniff out concealed drugs.

    Secondly, we have installed an instant urine test (IUT) machine to detect drug addicts coming into Singapore. Some of the addicts are what I described as 'ant-traffickers', that is, they traffic in small quantities of drugs so as not to attract capital punishment. Confirmed addicts are admitted to the Drug Rehabilitation Centres for treatment. Malaysian addicts are refused entry. From March to December 1988, 164 Singaporeans were detected and 533 Malaysians were refused entry. A total of 26 traffickers were also detected at the Woodlands Checkpoint.

    We are also stringent in issuing passports to ex-drug offenders and persons who are believed to want to travel for purposes of consuming drugs in Malaysia. In 1988, a total of 1,065 Singaporeans were denied passports.

    Central Narcotics Bureau will purchase more instant urine test (IUT) machines for use in their island-wide operations to identify and ferret out drug addicts. Marine Police will also intensify their patrols around Singapore waters and Customs will intensify their checks at all entry points. Members will have read recently, a large consignment of heroin, some 23 kg, was seized by alert Customs officers at Clifford Pier.

    To tackle the increasing number of Malay addicts, the Malay Anti-Drug Abuse Task Force working with other Malay/Muslim organizations is currently planning a strategy to tackle this problem. It will work very closely with my Ministry and SANA.

    Finally, Sir, a 2-month anti-drug campaign will be launched later this year to create public awareness and educate parents on the dangers of drug abuse.

     Dr Vasoo: Sir, could the Minister tell us the level of cooperation between Singa-

Column: 373

pore and the neighbouring countries in the control of drug trafficking?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, I would describe the level of cooperation as excellent. All the countries in Asean region as well as other countries further away realize that, to combat drugs and drug trafficking, there has to be cooperation and, in particular, exchange of information on patterns of trafficking as well as exchange of intelligence on specific syndicates and their movements. In particular, I would like to say that there is excellent cooperation between the Cawangan Anti-Dadah of Malaysia and the Central Narcotics Bureau in Singapore. It is this close cooperation and exchange of information which has allowed and enabled the countries to keep the incidents of drug trafficking to manageable proportions.

UNEMPLOYMENT STATISTICS


    4. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Labour if he will supply the latest unemployment statistics and the percentage breakdown by age groups.

     The Minister for Labour (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, as at June 1988, the unemployment rate was 3.3%. The unemployment rates by age groups were as follows: 

        Age Group            Unemployment Rate (%)



        15-24                         5.6

        25-34                         2.9

        35-44                         2.4

        45-54                         3.0

        55 & over                     1.8
The 15 to 24 age group had a higher unemployment rate because of the entry of fresh school leavers and graduates into the labour market.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Tiong Bahru GRC): Sir, will the Minister confirm that we have reached a stage of full employment?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Yes. 3%, I think, is equivalent to what is known as "frictional unemployment"; in other words, people moving in between jobs. But that does not mean that there are no people left who can be tapped from our labour market for employment. For example, there are about

300,000 Singaporeans who are above the age of 55, and about 75% of them are not working or looking for work. So if you can encourage them to continue working or re-enter the labour market, there will be a big potential labour force to be tapped.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Sir, the Minister has given us the percentage. Would he be good enough to let us know the numbers?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know whether the Member was present yesterday when I gave the answer to a similar question. Perhaps I could give him a copy of my reply.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of people who have registered for employment assistance with my Ministry has dropped from about 10,000 to the region of 4,000. The unemployment figure is actually assessed from our labour force survey. It is the sum total of people who are looking for jobs, not only people who are registered with the Employment Service.

     Mr Choo Wee Khiang: Sir, would the Minister consider allowing the existing foreign workers to take up part-time jobs so as to ease the labour shortage problem?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, this is something that has to be studied. The problem is how to control it so as to avoid abuse.

     Mr Loh Meng See (Kampong Glam): Sir, does the Minister have breakdown figures of the two sexes, how many of the unemployed are males and how many are females?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: I do not have the figures here. I can supply them to the Member if he wishes. Roughly, the percentage would be about two-thirds males and one-third females, corresponding to our workforce.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: A supplementary question, Sir.

     Mr Speaker: I will allow one more.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Would the Minister consider those people who work a couple of months a year and are actually semi-jobless as jobless people, Sir?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: We classify the unemployed as those people who are actively looking for a job and who do not have a job. I do not know what is the tendency of the Member's question. He seems to be trying to fish out the big army of unemployed that he referred to the other day. The fact is that we have more than 150,000 foreign workers.

FOREIGN MAIDS LEVY


    5. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Labour whether the increase in foreign maids levy runs counter to the Government's policy of encouraging more female participation in the labour force.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no contradiction between the increase in the foreign maids levy and the policy to encourage more Singaporean women to work. It is not the Government's intention that any particular policy should be pursued to its ultimate limit regardless of other consequences. There has to be a balance between the various policies.

    Employing a foreign maid is only one of several options available to women who have to work and who have to cope with household and childcare responsibilities. The other options are:

    (i) The married woman stops work after childbirth and returns to work after the children are older and more independent;

    (ii) Part-time or home-based employment;

    (iii) Traditional help from parents, in-laws, relatives and neighbours;

Column: 376



    (iv) Foster-care;

    (v) Childcare centres;

    (vi) Sharing of household duties among family members; and

    (vii) Local domestic help, mainly part-time.

    Sir, there are over 40,000 foreign maids in Singapore today as compared to a total of 630,000 households. Clearly, the vast majority of Singaporean families have managed to cope without maids, either local or foreign. Many developed countries with higher female participation rates than Singapore (eg, Switzerland, Japan and Australia) do not depend on foreign maids.

    My Ministry recognizes that it is not easy for working parents, especially mothers, to juggle their job demands with their childcare and household responsibilities. However, employing a foreign maid should not be the only or even the main solution to the problem.

    The growing number of foreign maids shows that we are heading to a situation where employing a foreign maid is seen by many as the only option. We should avoid this for various reasons:

    Firstly, the large number of foreign maids poses long-term social problems and increases demand on our public facilities such as medical services and transportation.

    Secondly, the long-term effects on the values and work ethics of children brought up by foreign maids are still unknown and therefore we should be cautious.

    Thirdly, other local alternatives for childcare and housekeeping will not develop fully. This will affect those who cannot afford to have maids.

    Employing a foreign maid has assisted some Singaporean women to continue working. However, the situation becomes untenable if most working women require maids. The number of maids will then become extremely large. There are 207,000 Singaporean wives who are working and most of them are managing without maids.

Column: 377



    The number of foreign maids in Singapore has shot up from almost zero in 1978, when the foreign maids scheme started, to more than 40,000 today. As the number is still growing rapidly, the Government has no alternative but to take measures to dampen the demand.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Cheng San GRC): Sir, since the Minister is quite impervious to other forms of proposals, except the financial one, I would like to suggest this proposal. Will he consider a form of progressive rate on the levy? That means those who earn less probably pay slightly less than those who earn more. In fact, another form would be a modification of this. Those who employ a second maid probably would have to pay a higher levy. And those who employ a third maid would pay a still higher levy.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know what the Member meant when he said that I am quite impervious to other suggestions.

    As for his question about differential levies, the problem is that from a national viewpoint, the social cost of a maid is the same, whether she is employed by A or by B. And do you want to enter into a situation where we have different pricing of the same services to different people because of different incomes?

    As for pricing the levy higher for second maids, this will not solve the problem because less than 5% of the families have more than one maid, in other words, they have two maids. And the Ministry does not, in general, allow any family to have more than two maids. In fact, most singles do not qualify for maids. Already there are administrative controls to try and dampen the number of maids. We have tried to defer this increase in the levy for a long time. But unfortunately the numbers have gone up and so I am compelled to take this action.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Sir, may I give a point of clarification first when I said the Minister is impervious?

     Mr Speaker: I am sorry. Ask your question, please.

Column: 378



     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Sir, my question is this. If the Minister is so concerned about the numbers increasing, then I would like him to look at any scheme, any idea, that can dampen the numbers to any extent and it would surely be in line with his objective.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, I would say yes that my Ministry will welcome all suggestions on ways to tackle this problem. I realize that this is a complex issue, that working mothers deserve help, that we want the women to have children, to work and so on. So it is really a very complex issue that even countries like Japan cannot resolve, if you refer to a newspaper report a few days ago about the problems of working mothers in Japan. Sir, if Members have good suggestions, my Ministry will consider them.

    There is one school of thought which says that we should allow only people who need maids to have maids. That is one school of thought. I do not know whether we want to go to that extreme. If I may remind you, ours is a free market economy. So we depend on a mixture of pricing and administrative controls. In socialist countries, there is this statement, "From each according to his ability and to each according to his needs." Do we want to go that way, such that even if you can afford to pay for a particular service, the State says you cannot have it because you do not need it?

    I was following closely the debate the other day about problems of working mothers and I sympathise with them. We have taken this action because there was no alternative. We already have administrative controls in place since 1987. But the numbers are still going up so rapidly that the number of maids could double in maybe five years. So we have to do something. If you can come up with better ideas, please let me know.

     Dr Koh Lam Son (Telok Blangah): Sir, if it is the case as the Minister has stated that the majority of families can actually cope without maids, then why did the Government allow maids in the first place; and, secondly, why allow increasingly large numbers over the years?

Column: 379



    The second question is that if we are only going to allow families who need maids to have maids, what will be the criteria that the Minister will use?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I was not the Labour Minister when the door was opened to foreign maids. Looking back now at this policy, it has its good and bad points. Certainly, it has helped a lot of working women, the better qualified and those who can afford maids to come out and work. And as a result, the female participation rate has gone up. So it has been a good policy. On the other hand, we cannot have too much of a good thing. So we have to control it. In fact, most mothers cannot afford maids with or without a levy. So other solutions must be found and childcare centres could be one of them.

    On the other hand, I think we should avoid a situation where the family or average Singaporean tends to look to Government for solutions to every problem. The traditional solution has been for the grandmother to look after the grandchild. Unfortunately, with the easy availability of maids, I have had cases at my Meet-the-People sessions where the chap comes in and says, "My mother-in-law used to look after the child for me. But now she says, "Why don't you get a maid because I am already 50 and I want to enjoy my life? So why don't you have a maid?"" This is a trend that is coming and we must try and arrest this tendency. One consequence of this development could be the loss of this opportunity to inculcate in our young the social values of the older folks.

    As regards his other question, I think he missed my point. I did not say that we should allocate maids according to needs. In fact, I am saying that we should allow a mixture of policies - needs, for example, where they have sick parents as well as other instruments like the levy.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Sir, when the Minister mentioned about the grandmother, does he mean that he thinks grandmothers should not be allowed to enjoy themselves?

Column: 380



     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know whether the Member was joking. I presume he was. Of course, I did not mean it that way. It is perfectly all right for everybody to relax and have a good time. But I am saying that there are, in fact, a lot of older women who are at home and looking after children, whether their own, their grandchildren or other people's children. This is, in fact, a good source of income for these people. So if you allow other sources, more foreign maids for example, they will be depriving these people of their income.

ECONOMETRIC MODEL
(Accuracy)


    7. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Trade and Industry what is the degree of accuracy of his Ministry's econometric model for Singapore in view of the sharp variance between the actual and forecast 1988 economic performance.

     The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Mr Mah Bow Tan) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, in December 1987, the MTI forecast growth for 1988 at 5-6%. Actual growth turned out to be 10.9%, much better than expected.

    On a sectoral basis, MTI predicted growth of the construction and the financial and business services sectors reasonably well, but grossly under-estimated growth in the other three sectors, namely,

Column: 381

manufacturing, commerce, and transport and communications. Commerce grew three times faster than expected, while manufacturing and transport and communications grew twice as fast.

    The economy in 1988 benefitted from unforeseen changes in external conditions. In December 1987, when we made our first forecast, our index of leading indicators had been declining for three months. After the stock market crash of 19 October 1987, the outlook for the world economy was subdued. But as it turned out, there was no post-crash global recession in 1988. Instead of slowing down, the US economy grew by nearly 4%, or twice the original forecast.

    There were sectoral factors as well. Strong worldwide demand for disk drives buoyed the manufacturing sector. The high Yen and the upturn in regional economies brought us record numbers of tourists. Transport and communications expanded on the heels of the manufacturing and commerce sectors.

    Sir, economic forecasting is always uncertain, however good the econometric model. Many events are unforeseeable and cannot be anticipated by any model. We can only update our models with fresh data on a regular basis and revise our forecasts during the year to improve their accuracy.

    MTI also has to bear in mind that an over-optimistic forecast may do more damage, in terms of mistaken Government policies, ill-founded business expectations and excessive wage settlements than a slightly conservative one. MTI therefore prefers, if need be, to err on the side of caution. When growth exceeds our expectations, as it did in 1988, we are glad to be proved wrong.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok: Sir, the general belief is that to the Government's prediction we should add 1% more to the growth to get the actual. In view of what has happened, how many percentage points will the Minister advise that we should take into account now?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, MTI forecast growth for 1989 at 6-7% and the Member realizes that this was only released some

Column: 382

three weeks ago. Barring unforeseen circumstances and in the light of the data that we have, I must advise that the estimate is the best that is currently available. But of course, as I said, if we are proven wrong and growth exceeds our forecast we will be glad.

     Dr Wan Soon Bee (Pasir Panjang GRC): Sir, the Minister has said that the forecast is not accurate and I do agree that a variance of 10-15% is acceptable. But in this case, I think the variance has been very big, from 6-7% to about 10.9%. This will make the forecast quite valueless and meaningless.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I explained in my reply just now, the forecast was made at the end of 1987 and, as it turned out, actual growth, as the Member rightly pointed out, was much more. But there were extenuating circumstances as to why the forecast in the end turned out to be wrong. As I have indicated earlier, MTI will revise its forecast on a quarterly basis.

INCREASE IN BUSINESS COST
(Fear of recession)


    8. Mr Choo Wee Khiang asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether he will comment on the fears expressed by some members of the business community that the increases in the foreign workers levy, the employers' contributions to the Central Provident Fund and road tax may drive up business cost and push the economy into another recession.

    Sir, I think it would be better if response to feedback is given prior to announcing a policy. In this way, the Government will be seen to have given the feedback full consideration. Prompt response to feedback, I think, should be an integral part of the consultative process. One good example to illustrate this is when the Minister for the Environment announced his decision last Wednesday not to introduce the compulsory use of disposable crockery after consideration of the feedback from the hawkers.

    Next, a more educated electorate expects fuller explanations on decisions taken by the Government, Government agencies and the civil service. When this is not forthcoming, they get frustrated. For example, when the increase in the foreign maid levy was first announced, no explanation was given. An explanation was only forthcoming when a Member tabled an Oral Question to the Minister for Labour last Wednesday.

    Another example relates to replies given by the various Government departments. Although explanations are sometimes given but, by and large, the appeals are rejected without proper explanations. The standard reply one receives is that the appeal has been carefully considered and that it cannot be accommodated. Sir, this is not satisfactory. Specific reasons for the rejection should be given unless the reasons are of a very sensitive nature.

    Another problem in the consultative process is the public image of our policy makers. It is important for our leaders to

Column: 401

reveal more of the humane side of themselves to the public. I read with great interest a letter in the forum page of the Straits Times recently. The reader expressed surprise at the care and concern that our First Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Goh Chok Tong, showed to his friends. He had the impression that Mr Goh is a very cold and uncaring person and this influenced his voting in the last general elections.

    Sir, the same impression may have been given by other Ministers. The electorate may feel that our Ministers are detached and unfeeling when announcing and implementing policy, especially the harsh one. Sir, more needs to be done to project and bring across the human side of our leaders to the people. This will help to dispel the misconceptions and fears that Singaporeans have.

    Last week, I watched the TV programme "Contact Y" which was referred to by the Member for Ayer Rajah and I too was shocked by the view expressed by some of the participants in the forum who felt that they could not speak freely because of a "climate of fear". When I asked him what he and his friend thought of the National Ideology, he told me that they had talked about it and they felt that it was a PAP's ploy.     Sir, next, I would like to touch briefly on the National Ideology. I believe that the National Ideology is good for Singapore. It will foster even closer ties between the various communities and help us to achieve greater unity. Much has already been said and it appears that we have managed to identify some important values which are likely to be accepted by the majority of the communities in Singa-

Column: 402

pore. These are multi-racialism, religious tolerance, consensus, emphasis on the family unit and placing community above self.

    Sir, the more important question now is how to implement the National Ideology when it is formulated and make it work. No concepts or ideals can be translated into practice and internalize without effective implementation. The Government should identify ways of rewarding those who practise these ideals in order to encourage them. Singaporeans are a pragmatic people. That is why we are able to make such progress. If the National Ideology continues to remain vague and does not impact on Singapoeans in a real and immediate way, I fear little will be achieved.      Dr Aline K. Wong (Tampines GRC): Thank you, Mr Speaker, Sir, for giving me the chance to participate in this debate.

    I find the clarifications made by the Second Deputy Prime Minister in yesterday's debate on the meaning of "chauvinism" to be very significant indeed. And therefore I would like to begin my speech on one aspect which was touched on during our current debate on the National Ideology.

Column: 403



    When we are deliberating on something as important an issue as the National Ideology which is meant to be a common set of core values for all the communities in Singapore, we are bound to encounter, as indeed we have already encountered, very different viewpoints from the various racial communities. And these reactions, I think, indicate that racial sensitivities are involved in many of our discussions and that we have to be very careful in trying to handle these public discussions throughout the country.

    The minority communities, when they are asked to express their opinion on the National Ideology, are justifiably concerned. They are wondering whether the Chinese values might be imposed on all the minority communities. Specifically they ask whether Confucianism is actually meant for all Singaporeans. Now that the Government has made it abundantly clear that the purpose of the National Ideology exercise is to search for values which are common to all the communities and that consensus is the method by which this set of common values would be arrived at, I hope such anxieties on the part of the minority groups will be sufficiently allayed.

    Interestingly, the Chinese community is also asking some similar questions on the National Ideology. Does the National Ideology mean that they also have to adjust their values? They are actually quite confused by the Government's call for the preservation of traditional values on the one hand, and the repeated warnings against cultural chauvinism on the other. Among the Chinese educated especially, many feel that the Government has been giving out quite conflicting signals. Their hopes for a return to cultural traditions have been raised because of the Government's emphasis on preservation of traditional values. But whenever the warning against chauvinism is sounded, I think they feel that their hopes are also dashed to the ground again. The older Chinese population, in particular, feel that the word "chauvinism" conjures up very unpleasant memories. The term is linked to the Communist and communalist threats of the 1950's and 1960's. Of course,we have

Column: 404

learnt a very bitter lesson from that turbulent period in our history and the mistake must not be repeated again. But when the term "chauvinism" is used within the present-day context, one wonders if it is still appropriate. There are some people who are even cynical enough to ask: "Is it not possible for other communities to develop their own kinds of chauvinism as well?" And "What about other people who think that everything from the west is best? Would it not constitute some form of western chauvinism also?"

    So it is in this light that, when I heard the Second Deputy Prime Minister's remarks and his clarification on the meaning of chauvinism, to quote him, "When we talk of learning Chinese culture and values through the use of Chinese for the Chinese, it is not chauvinism, and that when other races think about acquiring or learning their traditional cultures and values through their own mother tongues, it is also not chauvinism", I find that very very timely and very good indeed. I think this kind of clarification, this kind of reassurance to all communities concerned must be made, otherwise I think the Chinese community, in particular, would feel that they do not really know what the Government is driving at.

    The above aside, it is still necessary for us to take a closer look at what most of the Chinese want out of a policy on cultural preservation in the present-day context. Whether they speak Mandarin well or none at all, few of them would still identify themselves with the Chinese in China. What they want out of a policy on cultural preservation is based on what they see as a vacuum in the lives of their children, in the lives of their younger generation. They see it happening. So they yearn for some ways to give back to their children a cultural identity that will help them to face the vicissitudes of life with greater confidence and a sense of purpose. And that is all. Column: 405



    One should also note that among the Chinese not all embrace Confucianism in its totality. In fact, many among the Chinese think that Confucian values need to be modified to suit today's modern circumstances. One issue involved is the relationship, or how Confucianism is reconcilable with modern democratic values. He specifically mentioned that Confucian tradition places a premium on a Government which is based on moral authority, leaders who lead by moral example and acting in accordance with what wisdom and morality would dictate as a public good in the interest of the people. In other words, a model quite different from the mechanistic or simplistic model of western democracy. So that is one issue I think we have to thoroughly thrash out because many of the Chinese do not agree necessarily with the view that Confucianism is conducive to democracy.

    A second issue that also has to be thrashed out is the role of the family. The ideology of the family or family values occupy a very central position in Confucianism. But how are we going to reconcile this with the fact that, again, the lives of the people have changed much, aspirations of the people have changed much and we have witnessed in the last few days a raging debate on child care centres, on the foreign maids levy, on the participation of women in the labour force. So in other words, there are really some contradictions in the way we look at the role of the family and the role of women in the kind of society that we want. The Minister for Labour did not admit as much. He gave a very clever answer. He said no policy (unless I heard him mistakenly), no policy should be pushed to the extreme. But he seemed to be saying, "Yes, we do not know really what to do about these conflicting demands but the best solution is probably the medium or the golden rule of the mean." I hope he would not feel

Column: 406

upset if I misinterpreted him. But my point is that this is a second issue that many people would hope to be resolved when we debate Confucian values and family ideology.

    As far as the question of the second language policy is concerned, I think some people still think that the teaching of traditional values need not be done through the mother tongue. This happens mainly among the group of Chinese who were English educated. It is not their fault that they did not have the opportunity to receive an education or receive some language skills in the second language when they went to school. They may not even use dialects at home but they cannot help feeling that the Government's policy on language and culture has left them in a peculiar, if not uncomfortable, position. So they examine their own lives. They have done well. They have moved up in society and they have made contributions. So, like the Member for Potong Pasir, they ask, "What is wrong with westernization?" I think to address the anxieties of this group of English educated people we need to reiterate the message that the return to cultural values, the teaching of traditional values through the second language policy is really meant for the next generation. It is really directed at the younger people. Nobody need feel hurt or need feel uncomfortable. If he or she does not speak Mandarin or the mother tongue it does not matter. It is directed at the second generation. Granted, the greater concern of the English educated is over the problems faced by the children in coping with the study of CL2. They fear the children's future will be affected if they cannot cope. Thus one hears very frequently that professionals are leaving or intending to leave Singapore because of the Government's second language policy. If this is the main reason for the emigration of professionals, actually I personally doubt whether this is indeed the main reason, but I have no evidence to show, but even if it is the main reason, perhaps something can still be done about the method of teaching the second language. But I would not agree with any further lowering of the standard required because here we are talking not just about a minimum standard of proficiency as a means of communication or as a communicative skill. Here we are

Column: 407

talking about a minimum standard of proficiency for the transmission of cultural values.

    Yesterday the Member for Braddell Heights gave a very interesting table to the House which showed the L2 results at both the 'AO' level for GCE 'A' level students as well as the L2 results for GCE 'O' level examinations for the last three years. It is abundantly clear from these statistics that the percentage of people passing CL2 at both the 'AO' level and the 'O' level has been more than 90%, in fact around 95-96% throughout these recent years. So I think again the anxiety of the English educated parents who give the problem that their children have with CL2 as a reason for intending to migrate must be allayed again. Based on these figures it is clear that the children would not have a problem in coping with CL2, particularly now that the Government has given clear indications that we are not changing the list of vocabulary or raising the standard of the language course required.

    Let me move very quickly to a different theme in our debate. The concern for the lower income groups is a very major concern as expressed in the President's Address, and as the Minister of State for Community Development and Education in her maiden speech expressed over the impact of the rising health care cost on the lower income groups. This is also one of the major issues which my GPC has in the last two years taken up with the Acting Minister for Health and his Ministry. We have repeatedly called upon the Government to pay special consideration to the lower income families since they would be the most affected by the restructuring of the Government hospitals. The answer given by the Acting Minister for Health on this question has always been in the following manner. In fact,he gave the same answer to the Minister of State for Community Development and Education two days ago. He pointed out that the occupancy rate of C-class beds has gone down from 73% in 1980 to 65% today. This, he said, shows that even the lower income groups can afford the B2 wards. We know that in fact, parallel to the decrease in the number of C-class beds in

Column: 408

Government hospitals, there has been an increase in the number of B2 ward beds. But does he not think that the reason, at least a very important reason for this drop in the demand for C-class beds may very well be on account of Medisave? A large proportion of Medisave members actually have balances of less than $1,000 and this amount is not going to last them very long, especially if they fall seriously ill. Since Medisave is money locked away unless it is used, people who can actually ill afford B2 beds are tempted to use it. Another fact is that many people actually do not realize that the difference between a B2 ward bed and a C-class ward bed is more than just a difference in the ward charges and the meal charges per day. The statistics may not show it but I think the reason is there and the Ministry should very well take a closer look into this matter - the use of Medisave and how, in fact, the lower income families have been using Medisave unwisely for B2, apart from the question that the rise in the charges, ie, the differential between C and B2 beds has now been quite steep in the recent 1988 exercise.

Column: 409

given waivers. My point is: how stringent are the criteria for application? If people go and ask, say, the medical social worker for consideration of waiver, the first piece of information that the social worker will inquire is how much is their household income and if they do not qualify they cannot apply.      The Senior Minister of State for Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to speak in support of the motion standing in the name of the Member for Siglap. Sir, I will speak specifically on two topics, namely, religion and politics, and the Elected President proposal.

    May I speak first on the Elected President proposal. Sir, I am in full agreement that we need a two-key system for the future. With so much at stake, it would be wise to provide for a second key to guard our reserves and to protect the integrity of the public service. No one doubts the wisdom of this. However, opinions differ as to the means to achieve this end. The Elected President is certainly one way to provide a check and balance. There are other ways which should be considered. An Elected President, because he is elected, will have the mandate to check the government and Parliament in the key areas in which he has been given power. But election has one disadvantage. It leads to polarization. In making the change, will we be in danger of losing the office of Head of State which at present is above politics and acts as a symbol to unify all our people? In our multi-racial society, I believe that a President who is above politics is important.

    Other alternative methods to achieve a two-key system should be considered. One could be a Presidential Council. The Council could be elected or appointed. Its main strength will lie in its ability to alert Parliament and the public if it should

Column: 410

disagree with the government of the day on the use of reserves or on key appointments. It could be as effective as the Elected President. I hope that this and other alternatives will be examined and I am glad that the Government in the President's Address has decided that the proposal will be fully discussed before a final decision is taken.

    On religion and politics. We have enjoyed real peace and harmony in Singapore for many years as far as matters of religious faith are concerned. This is despite the fact that we are a multi-racial, multi-religious society living in a small and crowded island. The more I think about this and compare ourselves with other countries bigger and better endowed than we are, the more I appreciate this fact.

    What has brought about this happy state of affairs? First and foremost, I believe that the vast majority of our people are pragmatic. They have exercised good sense and give and take in matters of religion. From time to time, there have been complaints about indiscriminate distribution of religious tracts. There have also been complaints about wind-blown ash and noise from religious ceremonies. The groups responsible for these have responded and generally moderate their practices. Good sense has prevailed and an easy accommodation of one another's practices has developed.

    The Government, the ultimate temporal authority of the land, has set a good example by being scrupulously fair and even-handed towards all religions. We are a secular state. The Constitution provides for freedom of worship for all our citizens. Religion is kept out of politics and the running of the country. It has not been allowed to become a factor in the social and economic life of our people. Imagine, Sir, how different the picture would be if it were otherwise, for example, if religion were a factor in job appointments, in educational opportunities or in the awarding of tenders and licences, practices which are common in religiously-biased states. There would be great indignation. We have been able to avoid this. The Government has not shown favour to any religious group nor has it discriminated against any group. It has been even-handed towards all groups.

Column: 411



    Sir, this happy state of affairs is likely to continue if religious leaders recognize that the right and proper function of religion is to meet the individual's spiritual and personal needs. From time immemorial, religions have provided an anchor and a compass for their believers. They embody core moral values and are responsible for transmitting them from generation to generation. They have contributed much to our society through welfare services, education and charitable works. All religions are primarily concerned with matters of the spirit and the transcendent.

    There are key events in everyone's life - birth, marriage and death. People experience happiness. They also experience distress and despair. At these times, many people turn to a religious faith. Religion has a unique role to play in being able to meet these personal needs. So long as religious organizations remember this, they will play a valuable role in our society. But if they should seek also to publicize themselves, to heighten their image and to impose themselves on others, this will lead to rivalry and competition from other religious groups. This will be the beginning of tension and disorder.

    Sir, it does not take much to arouse tensions. Insensitive job advertisements favouring applicants of a particular faith, careless and provocative remarks, even unintentional or intentional controversies started by letters to the press, these are enough to rouse emotions immediately. Religious sensitivities have arisen between different religious groups when criticisms are levelled by one group against another, usually by immature members of the group. Religious leaders have a responsibility to prevent such criticism. They should speak to the members of their group. They may by all means preach why their way is superior. But there is no need to denigrate others in doing so.

    Sometimes, in their enthusiasm for their faith, members of a religious group may decide to evangelize others without regard to whether they have espoused another religion. Some Christian groups do this. My advice to them is to refrain from doing so. There is a proper and orderly way for

Column: 412

evangelism. Faith should, first, be borne out by the way one lives. And secondly, it should never be forced on other people. Religious leaders should therefore keep clearly in their minds that their primary role is to meet the spiritual and the personal needs of individuals. If they do so, the chances of friction with other groups will be minimized.

    Sir, religious organizations or religious leaders should never try to seek political power or even to influence politics. This is a particularly dangerous minefield for them to get into. When a small group of Catholics and non-Catholics began to organize for radical change under the cover of properly constituted religious organizations they breached this important principle.

    World history is replete with horrendous examples of the consequences when religion becomes involved with politics. The problem of separating church or religion from the state is not a new one. The debate goes as far back at least to St Augustine. In Europe, right through the Middle Ages and the Reformation, religious groups sought to dominate by capturing political power. States joining forces with the Vatican or with the Protestant churches fought bloody wars with one another. In our own continent, Asia, we still witness slaughter and bloodshed when religious groups seek to assert themselves by moving into the public, political arena.

    In our multi-racial, multi-religious context, the consequences of such things would be worse. The entry of any religious group into the public arena no matter what their cause will invite a response from other religious groups who do not want to be outdone. The chaos that could follow would be as bloody as that arising from inter-racial conflict. The problem is that religion appears to provide an attractive and almost sacrosanct cover. Misguided religious leaders may act from this vantage point believing that the Government would be reluctant to act against them because the Government does not want to be seen to be anti-religion. Worse, political activists and Machiavellian idealists may decide, for the same reason, that they should also operate from behind the shield of religion and in the name of religion.

Column: 413



    Sir, is this scenario far-fetched and alarmist? I do not think so. We have only to look at the religious/ political civil wars taking place in countries not far from us Sri Lanka, the Punjab. There is also a world-wide revival and resurgence of all religions. Two great ideologies have dominated this century: Communism which has captured political power in almost half the world and Individualistic Humanism or Individualism as a philosophy which has captured the hearts and minds of many, particularly in the affluent West. They have both failed. The communist leaders, Mr Gorbachev and Mr Deng Xiao-ping have said as much in their speeches and in their actions. In the West, Individualism promised ever-increasing individual freedom and happiness and self-realization. It has also failed. It has instead produced the breakdown of the family, the drug culture and disillusionment.

    The traditional religions are making a come-back. People are looking to them for new solutions to their old problems. This explains the resurgence of all religions. We have practically all the major religions present in Singapore. The question is this: as they revive, what are the chances that they will come into rough contact with one another? What are the chances that those who seek radical social actions will exploit this revival to further their aims of revolutionary change?

    I am glad that the Government has recognized these dangers and will be looking into ground rules which will keep religion and politics separate. Such rules should not inhibit freedom of worship. The rules should seek to prevent the misuse of religion for political purposes. They should protect religion from abuse. I urge the Government to consult all religious groups as it formulates these rules, so that the intention and purposes will be clearly understood and accepted by all parties.

    Sir, I have no doubt that there are issues touching on moral or ethical principles which religious groups would want to draw attention to. These are legitimate grounds which may affect them in particular or society as a whole. There are two ways for them to handle these matters. The one way I do not recommend is that they take the matter to the public and organize pressure groups and publicity

Column: 414

campaigns. However worthy the cause, this is political action. It will invite reactions from other groups.

    The better way is for the religious group to communicate its views to the Government and to discuss the matter confidentially and frankly in private. Consensus, agreement and good sense is more likely to be reached by this approach. The Government should keep its channels of communication open.

    Sir, our Prime Minister said in a speech reported in the Straits Times on 14 December 1988, that Government Ministers and all Members of Parliament must serve all Singaporeans regardless of their religious beliefs. All Members of this House would surely concur with this. We are a secular state with a secular Constitution. The elected government is a secular government. Whatever our personal religious beliefs, we serve all Singaporeans regardless of their race, language or religion.

    However, Sir, I would like to add a corollary. I would like to ask that all religious groups should also recognize that this is a secular state. They should not expect special favours from Government. They should also avoid involving Government leaders and MPs publicly in their religious ceremonies and functions.

    I have two reasons for making this point. The first is this. If religious groups seek to involve government leaders and MPs in their religious activities, will this not lead to competition? All groups know that they will gain greater prominence if they can attract well-known public figures, like Members of Parliament, to attend their functions. This may be a perfectly normal human desire, but it will be a short step from this to competition by different religious groups for the attention, and even the patronage, of prominent state leaders. The converse will also be true. Political parties and politicians eager to win support will be tempted to move closer to certain religious groups. Where will it lead to? The competition and publicity can only excite feelings and increase rivalry and suspicion.

    My second reason is that mutual respect must work both ways. Government leaders and Members of Parliament have

Column: 415

their personal beliefs, including religious beliefs. Although they are public figures, it would be wrong for those of another faith to try to involve them in their religious ceremonies. Respect for another person's faith means that we should not intrude into his belief by involving him in the ceremonies of other religions. Some Members of Parliament have no personal objection in accepting invitations from any or all religious groups. It is, of course, their own choice which I respect. But if mutual respect is to mean something, religious groups should not expect or require all Members of Parliament to do the same.

    Sir, I have drawn a line for myself. I have declined official invitations from all groups to attend their religious ceremonies, although I have attended their functions which are not religious but are related to charity. I have also turned down official invitations by Christian groups to their religious activities although I am a Christian. It is not an easy line to draw because there will be some who will misunderstand the purpose. But if we believe that the separation is necessary especially in our context, then maintaining a certain distance between the state and all religions is important. If the two sides get too close to one another, religious friction and political involvement will be the result.

    In conclusion, Sir, Singapore has enjoyed an unprecedented period of religious peace and harmony. Religious leaders have been sensitive and sensible. They have sought quietly to meet their members' spiritual and personal needs. They should continue to concentrate on this. They have wisely not tried to seek publicity and to excite feelings. Let us keep it this way.

    There are many religious conflicts in the world today. Religious extremism and xenophobia in the world is on the rise again. This can affect our own religious groups which have connections and affinity with outside groups. It is in Singapore's interest as well as their own interest that religious leaders should be wise and keep their followers calm. Religion, like race, is visceral. Once it is aroused, its fury cannot be easily contained. To quote the

Column: 416

18th Century French philosopher Blaise Pascal, he said:

    'Men never do evil so completely and cheerfully as when they do it from religious convictions.' Religion when mixed with politics is an unholy and dangerous mixture. All parties must recognize clearly that a line exists between what belongs to the state and to politics and what belongs to religious faith and belief. If we do so, we will continue to enjoy peace.

work, to have "More Good Years", but a significant number wish to send a signal to this Government to register their protest and their frustration. I suspect this is not merely because it is new but more so because it is still an elusive subject, both exciting in what it purports to serve for us and in the questions and reservations on what it should indeed be. To be sure, the final word has yet to be said on this subject.

    Perhaps it is opportune for me at this juncture to put the National Ideology in its

Column: 450

proper perspective and context, if at all to clear the mist that has surrounded it when we started on Monday. I certainly cannot and do not want to pre-empt what it would be. But I can perhaps narrow the ground by asserting what it is not. Firstly, as has been indicated by the Minister for Trade and Industry and Second Minister for Defence, it will not have the force of law. And indeed, Sir, it should not be. For how does one compel citizens to imbue something as abstract as values and ethos through fines and jail terms? Rather it should be likened to a doctor's prescription which the patient is not legally bound to follow but nevertheless ignored at the risk of his health and even his survival.

    Second, it will not be a mechanism to impose the values of the majority community on the minorities, a fear often voiced by many Members in this House.

    Third, it is not intended to stifle individual freedom, initiative and creativity through the introduction of more communitarian values. And certainly, it is not meant to bury democracy in this country. The Minister of State for Finance and Foreign Affairs had argued eloquently yesterday why it should not and he saw no reason why it should not enhance democratic principles in our society.

    Neither, Sir, is the National Ideology anti-West, or a total denial of everything western, even those elements which are good for us and for all human beings. Rather it is to insulate us against what the Minister of State also aptly described "as the elevation of self over all societal considerations". Indeed, we should not sell ourselves short by shutting ourselves to good, wholesome values, regardless of where they hail from, so long as everyone here can be comfortable with them.

    These last two aspects should especially be made clear to, and understood, by younger Singaporeans. We should be mindful of the fears expressed by the Member for Toa Payoh GRC, Mr Davinder Singh, on the impact of the National Ideology on our youths. For unless they too accept the National Ideology, it will run the risk of rising and falling within just one generation.

    There is much to be done. Already Members who spoke had come out with a

Column: 451

multitude of values which they deem worthy of inclusion in the National Ideology. Apart from the four proposed by the President in his speech, many more were put forward that I had really lost count. Among them were parliamentary democracy, honesty, community welfare, concern for the poor, the list goes on. There were suggestions for the National Ideology to include values for workers, values in the workplaces, values in the home, values in the family, community, nation. And, Sir, this is just the tip of the iceberg. It occurred to me that we will not be short of suggestions on what values should be entrenched in the National Ideology. On the contrary, our job will be to choose from the array of suggestions, some of which may even conflict with each other, digest and distill them, those which are necessary and sufficient for us. As asserted by the Member for Bedok GRC, the National Ideology should be simple, relevant and practical. And according to the 1DPM just now, it has to be no less fundamental.

    On multi-racial, multi-religious, harmony, Sir, the clear and unanimous message from Members is that they are crucial to our country. Not only must we retain our record of harmony and co-existence, it will also be beneficial for us to improve such harmony and stability. Understandably, the strongest and most articulate proponents of this harmony are Members from the minority communities. Sir, this is not to imply that Chinese Members are less committed but that it is natural for the former to wish, to reiterate, to restate, these principles. For it is more comforting if these principles are indeed subscribed to by the whole society.

    So tolerance, understanding, sensitivity, these were the three ingredients mentioned and necessary for us to be able to live peacefully together, no matter what our heritage. Each of us will therefore have to reach out to the other, trust each other more. In the long run, I am of the conviction that we will need to desensitize racial issues and concerns.

    Sir, there was a suggestion by the Member for Potong Pasir whether it would

Column: 452

not be better for us to adopt the melting pot approach rather than for us to aim for an integrated society with each community keeping its own identity but remaining Singaporean in its perception of the country's goals, challenges, priorities and the sharing of a common destiny. To be fair to the Member, the melting pot may well be the utensil which this society ends up in, albeit not by design but by the natural run of things. But then again, the reality indicates that each community wishes to retain its own identity and uniqueness. Our job will be to ensure that this is met and this does not jeopardize the harmony, progress and stability of this nation.

    Let me now sum up the views on Government's style. The debate on this issue evoked a wide range of responses and stance, from plaintive pleas to more pointed and vociferous demands for people and MPs to have more say in running the country, for less Government control and for alternative, even dissenting views, to be heard without harassment. The civil service too was not spared and this was not the first time; neither will it be the last too. The Minister of State for Foreign Affairs and also the Member for Changi especially devoted virtually their whole speeches on what should and what should not be done by the civil service. For after all, it was seen by the people as synonymous with government. And rather ominously, the Minister of State for Communications and Information and Trade and Industry declared that there were indications that all was not well in this country; when more and more of our citizens, especially the more educated and talented ones, uproot themselves to settle in more congenial and preferred atmospheres in other countries. The challenge, as he put it, was how individuals could realize their personal aspirations within the constraints that we have. I agree that this will be one of the issues we have to seriously address ourselves to.

    Sir, the unanimous view was that our population has changed and so too have their aspirations and expectations. We will have to be, according to the Member for Bedok GRC, Dr Hong, "spiritually and psychologically in tune with the people"

Column: 453

and that perhaps our macho image needed a bit of restyling.

    I am glad that the Minister for Communications and Information has assured us that he and his Cabinet colleagues were committed to the spirit of consultation. What we would need to do now is to clearly demonstrate to the public that this commitment will be practised. This is especially important for younger Singaporeans. Again, as the Member for Toa Payoh GRC stated, we must continue to assure younger Singaporeans that we are sincere in wanting more openness and participation from the public. In his own words, there must be a visible interplay of contending forces. In other words, openness, flexibility, a more softer approach to govern should not rest only in commitment but should also be visible to the population.

    Apart from these three main issues, Sir, Members also brought up many other concerns but impossible for me to mention one by one. There was, however, a continuous thread weaving in and out of the fabric of the debate during these last five days and that is the concern for the low income, less fortunate, the poor of our society. There were calls for attention and help to be extended to them and to ensure that the goods and services that they would have to consume would be available to them and affordable to them, especially in the fields of education, health and housing.

    Sir, the proceedings in the debate will give us many things to mull over and many will, I am sure, surface again during the Budget debate in March. The President has indeed given us valuable food for thought. All that leaves me now is to close this debate by again thanking Members for their valuable contributions and the effort that they have taken in preparing for this debate. As for me, I cannot forgive myself if I leave this table without thanking you, Sir, for bearing with us and our ubiquitous text of speeches from your side of the Chamber. I know how you must feel and the restraint you must subject yourself to. Sir, you have presided over this 5-day debate with dignity, with firmness and with fairness.
